boat.name: Hanser
boat.full_description:
'Hanser's lifting keel alows the boat to sit on the mud and navigate shoal waters under engine. She was originally rigged as a gaff sloop and had an air cooled Ducatti diesel with a folding prop. In the right conditions and hands she is a very fast boat. Arthur Holt thinks this was the first boat to be fitted with a full size lifting keel of 3/4 ton, interchangeable gaff and bermudan rig.

Around 1986 she passed back into Arthur Holt's hands - he had a Bermudan rig built for another long thin boat called 'Kraken' which he transferred to 'Hanser', moving the mast back 5' onto the coachroof. He also made a gaff main which worked on the Bermudan mast so he could take part in OGA events.

Fabian Bush, who trained under Arthur, acquired the boat in 1999 and he started to change things. The engine was replaced by an outboard and a tiny mizzen added for handling under sail. The mast was moved back into the original position but on a tabernacle.

Latterly she has been sailed with a gaff main. The rudder and keel format have been altered and more ballast added for sail carrying capacity. A short bowsprit has been added, making the boat more of a family cruiser than a racer. A new mainsail was made in 2013 and a deeper analysis of the boat is planned.
boat.construction_details: Cold Moulded - 2 layers of khaya + external layer of teak over stringers and laminated frames and ply webs. Iroko centre resorcinal glue. Ply deck. Very light build akin to an aircraft
boat.short_description: 'Hanser' was designed and built for Nigel & Jean Willimot as a fast weekend sailer. Her hull is representative of the long narrow monohulls built for racing in the 1960s with deep high aspect ratio keel and rudder.
